questions.text: All of the following are seen in anemia of chronic disease except:
questions.solution:
Low serum ferritin levels are not seen in anemia of chronic disease.

Anemia of chronic disease is anemia resulting due to chronic diseases which produce systemic inflammation. During chronic inflammation, inflammatory mediators like interleukin - 6(IL-6) stimulate the production of hepcidin from the liver. Hepcidin is an acute phase reactant that inhibits ferroportin on macrophages and also decreases iron from stores to developing RBC precursors. This results in decreased proliferation of erythroid progenitors due to impaired iron utilization.

By decreasing available serum iron, the body defends itself from certain bacteria(Eg, Hemophilus influenza) that require iron for their pathogenicity. The lab findings seen in anemia of chronic disease are:

  • Low serum iron
  • Decreased total iron-binding capacity
  • Abundant stored iron
  • Increased hepcidin levels
  • Increased serum ferritin

The chronic illnesses associated with  anemia of chronic disease can be grouped into three categories:

  1. Chronic microbial infections, such as osteomyelitis, bacterial endocarditis, and lung abscess
  2. Chronic immune disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis and regional enteritis
  3. Neoplasms, such as carcinomas of the lung and breast and Hodgkin lymphoma

Note: Hepcidin is the main regulator of iron absorption which is encoded by the HAMP gene and is defective in hemochromatosis. 

Given below is an image of iron absorption that shows ferroportin being inhibited by hepcidin at intestinal mucosal cells

questions.text: Neurosecretory bodies are seen in all except
questions.solution:
Neurosecretory bodies are not seen in adrenal cortical tumours.

Most of the adrenocortical neoplasms are aldosterone-producing adenomas. Conn syndrome is primary hyperaldosteronism caused by a solitary aldosterone-secreting adenoma.

The clinical features of hyperaldosteronism are secondary hypertension and various neuromuscular manifestations resulting from hypokalemia.

Microscopically, aldosterone-producing adenomas are found to have eosinophilic, laminated cytoplasmic inclusions, known as spironolactone bodies, found after treatment with the antihypertensive drug spironolactone.

The image given below shows a microscopic image of spironolactone bodies found in adrenal adenomas

Other options:

Option A: Medullary thyroid carcinoma arises from parafollicular C cells and they produce calcitonin. They are associated with a point mutation in the RET proto-oncogene and multiple endocrine neoplasias (MEN 2A and 2B). Microscopically, polygonal cells in an amyloid stroma are seen. Electron microscopy reveals neurosecretory granules within the cytoplasm.

Option B: Pituitary adenoma may present with visual field abnormalities or pituitary apoplexy (acute haemorrhage into an adenoma). Prolactinoma is the most common type of hyperfunctioning pituitary adenoma. Histologically, prolactinomas are composed of chromophobe cells with cytoplasmic neurosecretory granules.

Option C: Adrenal medullary pheochromocytomas are the most common paraganglioma. Extra-adrenal paragangliomas occur in the head and neck at carotid bodies. Microscopically, carotid body tumours contain nests (zellballen) of chief cells. Electron microscopy shows well-demarcated neurosecretory granules.

questions.text:
Identify the true statement/s regarding clear cell carcinoma of the kidney
  1. Most common sporadic renal tumour
  2. Associated with loss of long arm of chromosome 3
  3. Arises from distal convoluted tubule
  4. Cells show intracellular accumulation of glycogen and fat
questions.solution:
True statements regarding clear cell carcinoma of the kidney are 1, 4. Clear cell carcinoma is the most common sporadic renal cell cancer and cells show intracellular accumulation of glycogen and fat.

Clear cell cancer arises from the proximal tubular epithelium and usually occurs as solitary unilateral lesions.

Most of the cases are sporadic, but can also occur either in familial forms or in association with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease. They are associated with the loss of sequence of the short arm of chromosome 3. Those with VHL disease inherit a germline mutation of the VHL gene on chromosomal band 3p25 and lose the second allele by somatic mutation.

The VHL protein causes the degradation of hypoxia-induced factors (HIFs), which are transcription factors that contribute to carcinogenesis by stimulating the expression of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) that helps drive tumour cell growth.

Histologically, the tumour cells have a rounded or polygonal shape and abundant clear or granular cytoplasm, which contains glycogen and lipids.

Given below is the histopathological image of clear cell carcinoma.

Cancerous cells produce various abnormal hormones resulting in paraneoplastic syndrome. These include polycythemia, hypercalcemia, cushing syndrome, amyloidosis and hypertension.

The most common site of metastasis is the lungs and bones. Radical nephrectomy is the treatment of choice. But T1a(size less than 4cm) tumours are treated by nephron-sparing surgery or partial nephrectomy to preserve renal function. Drugs that inhibit VEGF and tyrosine kinase inhibitors are used as an adjunct therapy for metastatic disease.

questions.text: The phenomenon of a differential effect of the same gene from different parents is called:
questions.solution:
The phenomenon of a differential effect of the same gene from different parents is called genomic imprinting.

Genomic imprinting refers to gene silencing/ inactivation. Here either the maternal or the paternal allele is inactivated resulting in only one functional allele. It occurs by the process of epigenetics, where gene expression is lowered by:

  • DNA methylation
  • Histone deacetylation

Genomic imprinting is best illustrated by two uncommon genetic disorders: Prader-Willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome.

Diagnosis of these syndromes is based on the assessment of the methylation status of marker genes and fluorescence in-situ hybridisation(FISH).

Option A: Gonadal mosaicism is a mutation that occurs only in egg or sperm cells and the individual will be phenotypically normal. These individuals with gonadal mosaicism can transmit the disease-causing mutation to the offspring through their mutated
gametes.

Option C: Anticipation refers to earlier onset of disease or increased severity in succeeding generations. This is seen in trinucleotide repeat disorders like Huntington's disease.

Option D: Incomplete penetrance refers to variations in penetrance and expressivity of clinical features. Not all individuals who inherit the mutant gene show a mutant phenotype.

questions.text:
Match the microscopic appearance in column A with the type of tumor in column B
Column A  Column B
1. Schiller Duval bodies a. Kruckenberg tumor
2. Presence of teeth, hair, etc b. Granulosa cell tumor
3. Signet ring cells c. Yolk sac tumor
4. Call-Exner bodies d. Teratoma
questions.solution:
The correctly matched option of the microscopic appearance with the type of tumor is 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b.

  • Schiller Duval bodies - Yolk sac tumor
  • Presence of teeth, hair, etc - Teratoma
  • Signet ring cells - Kruckenberg tumor
  • Call-Exner bodies - Granulosa cell tumor              

Schiller Duval bodies are seen in yolk sac tumors. A yolk sac tumor/endodermal sinus tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. Most of the yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic. These are glomerulus-like structures consisting of a central vessel surrounded by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

The image given below shows Schiller-Duval bodies seen in yolk sac tumors.

Presence of hair, teeth, etc is seen in teratomas. These are germ cell tumors. They contain embryonic tissues leading to the differentiation of cells along these pathways. Apart from teeth, hair may also contain skin, sebaceous glands, fat, bone, cartilage, etc.

There are three classes of teratomas:

  • Mature teratomas (eg - dermoid cyst)
  • Immature teratomas (eg - solid teratoma)
  • Monodermal highly specialized tumors (eg - Struma ovarii)

Given below is the histopathological image of immature teratoma of the ovary, with immature tissue of the bone (asterisk), cartilage (arrow), and islands of adipose tissue (arrowhead) 

Signet-ring cells are seen in the Krukenberg tumor. Krukenberg tumor is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasize to the ovary. Signet ring cells are mucin-producing cells. The appearance of a signet ring often originates from the gastric mucosa.

The image below shows signet-ring cells in the Kruckenberg tumor.

Option D: Granulosa cell tumours arise from granulosa cells which form part of the developing ovarian follicle. They are unilateral in nature and the mass is cystic and encapsulated. Call-Exner bodies are seen in granulosa cell tumors. These are gland like small structures with acidophilic material and immature follicles.

The image given below shows Call-Exner bodies seen in granulosa cell tumours.

questions.text: A patient suffering from cholelithiasis underwent cholecystectomy. The image of the specimen is shown below. Which of the following is the correct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The correct diagnosis in the patient is gallbladder polyp.

Gallbladder polyp is a pre-malignant condition that usually presents with biliary colic and cholecystitis. Cholesterol polyps are more common while adenomatous polyps have malignant potential.

Risk factors of malignancy in adenomatous polyp:

  • Age >60 years
  • Coexistence of gall stones
  • The documented increase in size
  • Size of >10 mm.

Polyps less than 1 cm can be followed with serial ultrasonography. The USG given below depicts gallbladder polyps that are fixed and do not cast any acoustic shadow. The polyps larger than 1 cm have an increased risk of malignancy and should be treated by performing an open cholecystectomy.

The image below shows an intraoperative photograph of gallbladder polyps.

The image given below shows the management of gall bladder polyp

Other options:

Options A and D: Cholesterosis or strawberry gallbladder is a condition characterized by a collection of submucous aggregations of cholesterol crystals and cholesterol esters in the gallbladder. The interior of the gallbladder looks like a strawberry with yellow specks.

The image given below shows the gross appearance of cholesterosis of the gallbladder

Option C: Gallbladder adenocarcinoma is the most common malignancy of the extrahepatic biliary tract. Gallstones are the most important risk factor. Her-2/neu is overexpressed and CA 19-9 is used for monitoring. The most important prognostic factor is the depth of invasion (T-stage). On gross appearance, they resemble chronic cholecystitis.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with swelling in the upper diaphyseal part of the tibia. X-ray of the swelling showed a periosteal reaction. A histopathological image of the biopsy is given below. Immunohistochemistry was positive for synaptophysin and mic 2. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing small round blue cells and immunohistochemistry (IHC) positive for synaptophysin and mic-2 point to a likely diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma. 

Ewing sarcoma is the 2nd most common bone sarcoma in children. The majority of the patients affected are usually <20 years of age. It has a slight male predominance. 

It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus and flat bones of the pelvis. The majority of Ewing sarcomas have a balanced translocation between the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 and the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11. 

Patients present with painful enlarging mass, fever, and anemia. The affected area is usually tender, swollen, and warm. Laboratory findings may show an elevated WBC count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). 

A histopathological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows sheets of uniform, round cells arranged in Homer-Wright rosettes. These cells are of neuroectodermal origin and have minimal cytoplasm and abundant glycogen. When they are arranged around a central fibrillary core in the form of clusters, the appearance is termed Homer-Wright rosettes. Immunohistochemistry is usually positive for synaptophysin and mic-2.

Given below is the histopathological appearance of Ewing sarcoma. 

As tumor cells are rich in glycogen, they stain positive for periodic acid Schiff (PAS) stain however, they stain negatively for reticulin.

The image given below shows PAS staining done in Ewing's sarcoma:

Radiological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of long bones. Deposition of periosteal reaction in layers gives an onion-peel appearance (shown below). 

Other options:

Option A: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignancy of bone. The histological features of osteosarcoma include pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and abundant mitoses. The diagnosis is definitive with the presence of malignant tumor cells producing unmineralized osteoid or mineralized bone arranged in a typically fine, lacelike pattern.

Given below is the histopathological image of osteosarcoma:

X-ray shows periosteal reaction and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunray appearance as shown below.

Option C: Neuroblastoma is a tumor of the sympathetic ganglia and adrenal medulla. It is derived from primordial neural crest cells. It is the most common extracranial solid tumor in childhood. On histopathology small round blue cells are seen. These cells are concentrically arranged around a faintly eosinophilic fibrillary material (neuropil). This appearance is called Homer-Wright pseudorosettes (shown below). 

Option D: Osteoclastoma is also known as a giant cell tumour. The tumor cells are primitive osteoblast precursors and express high levels of RANKL. Histologically, the tumors consist of osteoclast-type giant cells with 100 or more nuclei. These cells are usually present against a backdrop of mononuclear stromal cells. 

The image given below shows the histopathological appearance of giant cell tumour/osteoclastoma:

The image below shows an X-ray of a giant cell tumour showing the typical soap bubble appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following is a marker of natural killer cell?
questions.solution:
The marker of the natural killer cells is CD94. It is expressed in natural killer cells and a small subset of T lymphocytes. 

Natural killer cells (NK cells) are essential cells of innate immunity. They act against malignant and virus-infected cells. NK cells are identified by CD16 and CD56 cell surface receptors. 

NK cells' activity is augmented by interferons and upon activation, they bind to glycoprotein receptors on the surface of target cells and release perforins. Perforins create pores in the membrane of the target cells. Through these pores, cytotoxic factors like tumor necrosis factor-beta (TNF-β) enter the cells and destroy them by apoptosis.

NK cells express a phenomenon known as antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC). Here, NK cells have the capability of killing target cells that are coated by IgG antibodies.

The image given below shows the actions of NK cells on cancer cells.

Other options:

Option A: CD68 is expressed on macrophages and monocytes.

Option B: CD 3 is a T-cell receptor marker. They are involved in the transduction of signals to the T cells when an antigen binds to the T cell receptor.

Option C: CD 25 is a component of the IL2 receptor and is important in T cell proliferation and activation.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not caused by high-risk strains of human papillomavirus?
questions.solution:
Laryngeal papillomatosis is not caused by high-risk strains of human papillomavirus (HPV). It is caused by low-risk HPV strains 6 and 11. 

Laryngeal papillomatosis or juvenile papillomatosis is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children. It is caused by HPV 6 and 11. It involves supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx. Adult-onset laryngeal papillomatosis involves the anterior part of the vocal cords.

It usually occurs between the ages 3–5 years, but less commonly can also occur in men aged between 30-50 years. Clinical features include hoarseness or aphonia and respiratory difficulty. The recurrence rate is high but they rarely transform to SCC.

Diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy. Treatment consists of micro laryngoscopy, CO2 laser excision, and topical cidofovir.

The image given below shows laryngeal papilloma.

Other options:

Cervical cancer, anal cancer and oropharyngeal cancers are caused by high risk HPV types 16 and 18.

questions.text: A boy presents with recurrent episodes of melena. On examination, there was eczema of the skin with multiple petechiae. His platelet count was low but RBC and WBC counts were within normal limits. Which of the following is the diagnostic investigation in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of recurrent episodes of melena, eczema, and multiple petechiae along with low platelet counts is suggestive of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. The diagnostic investigation in this patient is WASP gene mutation testing. 

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome(WAS) is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder. It is caused by mutations in the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASp) that primarily affects the T lymphocytes.

Normally, WASp regulates the actin cytoskeleton and thus helps in cell adhesion, migration, and the formation of synapses between antigen-presenting and target cells. In WAS, there is a progressive loss of T lymphocytes in the peripheral blood resulting in defects in cellular immunity. 

The clinical features of WAS are recurrent bacterial infections, eczema, and bleeding due to thrombocytopenia. Patients with WAS are prone to develop B-cell lymphomas and autoimmune disorders.

The image given below shows eczema seen in WAS

Diagnosis is based on intracellular immunofluorescence analysis of WAS protein (WASp) expression in blood cells. IgM levels in the serum are low, but levels of IgG are usually normal. Reduced-sized platelet is a typical feature of WAS.

The only curative treatment is an allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant. Prophylactic antibiotics, immunoglobulin G (IgG) supplementation, and topical treatment for eczema can be tried. Gene therapy trials are also under research.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of innate immunity?
questions.solution:
B lymphocytes are not a part of innate immunity. B lymphocytes are part of adaptive immunity.

Innate immunity is an intrinsic mechanism that provides the first line of defence against infections. It is non-specific, provides immediate defence against microbes, and helps eliminate damaged cells.

  • Innate lymphoid cells (ILCs) - these are local tissue lymphocytes that lack T-cell antigen receptors. They produce inflammatory cytokines during the early phases of immune reactions. Gamma delta T lymphocytes and natural killer (NK) cells belong to this class
  • Mast cells
  • Complement pathway - it include complement proteins of alternative and lectin pathways.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern?
questions.solution:
Rett syndrome is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.

Rett syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder. It is caused due to mutation in the MECP-2 gene. The disorder is mostly seen in girls because affected boys usually die in infancy due to a defective single X chromosome.

Symptoms of Rett syndrome are microcephaly, developmental delay, autistic-like behavior, cognitive dysfunction, seizures, and repetitive motor actions.

Other options:

Option B: Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is inherited in X linked recessive pattern. It occurs due to a mutation in the dystrophin gene. Typical features include calf muscle pseudohypertrophy and Gower's sign (using arms to lift themselves from a seated position). Laboratory investigations show elevated serum creatine kinase levels. Casimersen has been recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of DMD.

Option C: Huntington's disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It is a trinucleotide (CAG) repeat disorder and shows genetic anticipation (earlier onset of disease or increased severity in succeeding generations). Patients present with involuntary movements known as chorea. Tetrabenazine is used for treatment.

Option D: Tuberous sclerosis also known as Bournville disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It occurs due to mutation in TSC1 and TSC2 genes. It is characterized by subependymal nodules, angiomyolipomas, cafe au lait spots, shagreen patches, and cardiac rhabdomyomas.

Entosis is a phenomenon where a cell engulfs a cell of the same type. While cells that are internalised by this mechanism are initially viable. But, the majority of them undergo a non-apoptotic form of cell death. It plays a physiological role in the elimination of cells detached from a surface.

Option C: Necroptosis is a type of cell death which is a hybrid of both necrosis and apoptosis. It is also called programmed necrosis/caspase-independent programmed cell death(since it does not result in caspase activation).

questions.text: Identify the cell marked in the image below
questions.solution:
The cell marked in the image is a mast cell stained with toluidine blue. Mast cell granules contain acid proteoglycan that binds basic blue such as toluidine blue.

Mast cells may be difficult to differentiate from lymphocytes in routine, hematoxylin, and eosin-stained sections, and special metachromatic stains (toluidine blue or Giemsa) are used to visualize their granules.

Mast cells are a part of innate immunity and are widely distributed in connective tissues. They play an important role in immediate hypersensitivity and both acute and chronic inflammation.

Mast cells express a receptor on their surface that binds to the Fc portion of the IgE antibody. When an antigen binds to IgE antibodies on the surface of the mast cell, they get activated and degranulate. This results in the release of:

  • Granule contents: Histamine, chymase, tryptase, heparin.
  • Lipid mediators: Leucotriene C4, D4, prostaglandin D2, platelet-activating factor.
  • Cytokines: Tumor necrosis factor, interleukin-1

These mediators released from mast cells play an important role in the pathogenesis of immediate/type 1 hypersensitivity.

The image given below shows the sequence of events in immediate (type 1) hypersensitivity.

Some of the important disorders associated with mast cell activity are bronchial asthma, urticaria, mastocytosis, interstitial cystitis and neurofibroma.

questions.text: How does phagolysosome cause cell death?

choices.text: Is both intra and extra cellular
Can fuse with other organelles directly
Fuses with lysosome to form autophagolysosome

questions.solution:
Phagolysosomes cause cell death by the fusion of lysosomes to form autophagolysosomes. 
Autophagy is a process in which a cell eats its own contents. Cytoplasmic materials are delivered and degraded by the lysosome. It is a survival technique of the cell in nutrient deprivation states. 

The steps are:

  • An isolation membrane called phagophore is formed and nucleated.
  • Phagophore is derived from the ER with the help of plasma membrane and mitochondria
  • A double membrane-bound vesicle is formed from the isolation membrane called the autophagosome
  • Maturation of the autophagosome by fusion with lysosomes, called autophagolysosome. 

Apoptosis is a regulated mechanism of eliminating unwanted and damaged cells. It is initiated by enzymes called caspases and is executed by two different pathways. The mitochondrial pathway which is also known as the intrinsic pathway carries out the majority of the apoptosis. The death receptor pathway or the extrinsic pathway is initiated by plasma membrane death receptors. Both these pathways combine together and activate the caspase cascade which results in the final phase of apoptosis. 

Pyroptosis is a form of apoptosis mediated by fever-inducing cytokine IL-1. A multiprotein complex called inflammasome is activated when microorganisms enter the cell. It will in turn activate caspase 1 which cleaves the IL-1 precursor and releases its biologically active form.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with complaints of fatigue and dyspnea for 2 weeks. On examination, pallor was seen and hemoglobin was found to be 6 gm/dL. What finding will be seen on peripheral smear?
questions.solution:
Microcytic hypochromic cells will be seen on the peripheral smear. An elderly female presenting with fatigue and dyspnea with severe anaemia is suggestive of iron deficiency anaemia(IDA). The peripheral smear of IDA shows microcytic hypochromic red blood cells.

Iron deficiency is the most common nutritional disorder in the world. IDA results from dietary deficiency, impaired absorption, increased requirement and, chronic blood loss. The cause of iron deficiency anaemia in an older man or post-menopausal woman is always gastrointestinal cancer until proven otherwise.

Clinical presentation may include fatigue, pallor, dyspnea, cheilosis (fissures at the corners of the mouth) and koilonychia (spooning of the fingernails).

Peripheral smear in IDA shows:

  • Microcytic hypochromic red blood cells with an enlarged zone of central one-third pallor.
  • Poikilocytes: pencil-shaped RBCs and, target cells.

The image given below shows a microcytic hypochromic blood picture in a peripheral smear

IDA is treated by giving oral, parenteral and packed cell transfusions depending on the severity of anaemia.

For oral iron replacement therapy,

  • Up to 200mg of elemental iron is given.
  • According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat initiative, adult women need to take 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid tablets once a week.

For parenteral iron therapy, the amount of iron needed by an individual is calculated by the formula:

Body weight(kg) x 2.3 x (15 - patient's hemoglobin, g/dL) + 500 or 1000mg (for stores)

questions.text: The image below is indicative of which of the following tumors?
questions.solution:
The image shows the characteristic Schiller Duval body consistent with a yolk sac tumor. 

A yolk sac tumor/endodermal sinus tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It originates from embryonal structures of the yolk sac by selective differentiation.

It is most oftenly seen in children and young women. It usually presents as abdominal distention and a palpable pelvic mass. 

Grossly, the yolk-sac tumor appears yellow, friable (hemorrhagic), and forms solid mass.

Most of the yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic. These are glomerulus-like structures consisting of a central vessel surrounded by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

The image given below shows Schiller-Duval bodies seen in yolk sac tumors.

Yolk-sac tumors are rich in alpha-fetoprotein. Therefore, serum levels of alpha-fetoprotein can serve as a reliable tumor marker in post treatment surveillance.

Option C: Krukenberg tumor is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasize to the ovary. It is characterized by mucin-producing signet ring cells. The appearance of a signet ring often originates from the gastric mucosa.

The image below shows signet-ring cells in Kruckenberg tumor.

Option D: Granulosa cell tumours arise from granulosa cells which form part of the developing ovarian follicle. They are unilateral in nature and the mass is cystic and encapsulated. Call-Exner bodies are seen in granulosa cell tumours. These are gland like small structures with acidophilic material and immature follicles.

questions.text: A child presents with multiple skin lesions over the inner thigh and genital areas. It initially started as macule and later developed to become nodules. Some nodules have central umbilication. The histology of the lesion is shown below. What would be found on biopsy?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histological image are diagnostic of molluscum contagiosum lesions, which show intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies, called Henderson–Patterson bodies or molluscum bodies.

Infection is usually spread by direct contact, particularly among children and young adults. Multiple lesions occur on the skin and mucous membranes, with a predilection for the trunk and anogenital areas. Individual lesions are firm, pruritic, pink to skin-colored umbilicated papules. A curd-like material can be expressed from the central umbilication.

Smearing this material onto a glass slide and Giemsa staining shows diagnostic molluscum bodies, which are ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusions that are found in the cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum and are up to 35 μm in size.

 

 

Other options:

Option A: Multinucleate giant cells (called Tzanck cells) are seen in herpes simplex virus infections. They are formed when individual epidermal cells containing viral inclusions fuse to produce giant cells. These can be demonstrated by the diagnostic Tzanck test, which is based on the microscopic examination of the vesicle fluid.

Option B: Donovan bodies are seen in donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. Donovan bodies are minute, encapsulated coccobacilli in macrophages, which can be demonstrated in Giemsa-stained smears of the exudate.

Option D: Koilocytes are characteristically seen in HPV infections, such as condylomata acuminata. Koilocytes are lining cells that have perinuclear cytoplasmic vacuolization.

questions.text: Investigations of a patient being evaluated for leukemia revealed a WBC count of 4,50,000/μL, with eosinophilia and basophilia. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A WBC count of 4,50,000/μL with eosinophilia and basophilia indicates a probable diagnosis of chronic myelogenous leukemia.

CML is a myeloproliferative neoplasm. It is caused by the translocation of ABL gene on chromosome 9 onto BCR gene on chromosome 22, resulting in the formation of the BCR-ABL fusion gene. This chromosomal abnomality, called Philadelphia chromosome, is characteristic of CML.

The resulting BCR-ABL translocation results in the activation of tyrosine kinase that signals pro-growth and pro-survival pathways like RAS and JAK/STAT pathways resulting in the proliferation of hematopoietic stem cells.

Patients typically present with a dragging sensation abdomen due to splenomegaly or splenic infarct, fatigue, malaise, and weight loss.

On peripheral smear there is leukocytosis with leukocyte count, often exceeding 100,000 cells/mm3 (neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils), blasts are usually less than 10% of the circulating cells, the platelet count is usually increased. Basophils and eosinophils are often increased.

Other options:

Option D: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a hematopoietic progenitor malignancy that causes immature myeloblast accumulation in the bone marrow.  Incidence increases with age and peaks after 60 years of age.

The WBC count is about 15,000/μL. Few cases have either <5000 or >1,00,000/μL WBC count. Clinically, the patients present with symptoms resulting due to pancytopenia (anemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia). For acute myeloblastic leukemia (AML) diagnosis, the blast cell count should be ≥20% in the peripheral blood or bone marrow

Other distinctive features of AML include

  • Bone marrow/ peripheral smear shows a large, uniform population of cells (myeloblasts) with prominent nucleoli (yellow arrow). It shows the presence of primary cytoplasmic granules
  • Auer rods: needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies formed by the fusion of lysosomes. (black arrow)
  • Multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks known as faggot cells (seen in peripheral smear).

Option A: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) arises from immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells called lymphoblasts. Most cases present with a reduced or normal lymphocyte count. Blood counts show anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia.

Immunohistochemistry for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) is positive in pre-B and pre-T lymphoblasts. Peripheral smear shows lymphoblasts that have condensed chromatin, less conspicuous nucleoli, and smaller amounts of cytoplasm which lacks granules as shown below.

Option C: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia presents with a mean WBC count of 30*109/L. It is associated with the deletions of 13q, 11q, 17p, and trisomy 12q. 

Lymph nodes are diffusely effaced by small lymphocytes with proliferation centers. The image shows small round lymphocytes and smudge cells seen in CLL.

questions.text: Which of the following molecules helps the leukocytes roll over the endothelial cells in the vessels?
questions.solution:
E-selectin, which is present over the endothelium, helps the leukocyte roll over the endothelium.

Selectins are of 3 types: L-selectin present on leukocytes, E-selectin present on the endothelium, and P-selectin present in platelets and on the endothelium. 

The weak rolling action slows down the leukocytes and allows them to bind more firmly to the endothelium with the help of integrins.

The recruitment of leukocytes to the site of injury involves the following steps:

  • Lumen of the vessel to the endothelium:
    • Margination: Leukocytes assume a peripheral position along the endothelial surface because of the stasis of blood flow.
    • Rolling: Leukocytes start rolling on the vessel wall because of signaling molecules from the endothelium.
    • Adhesion: Leukocytes are attached to the endothelium because of adhesion molecules that are activated by cytokines. 
  • Transmigration of the leukocytes across the vascular endothelium.
  • Migration towards a chemotactic stimulus in the extravascular tissues.

 

Other options:

Option A: Cadherins are a type of glycoprotein cell adhesion molecule that allows cells to adhere together.

Option B: Platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule-1 (PECAM-1), aids in diapedesis, which is the movement of leukocytes through intact endothelium of the capillaries to reach the site of injury.

Option D: Cd11a, a molecule from the integrin family, helps firmly adhere the leukocyte to the endothelial cell.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true about hereditary spherocytosis?

choices.text: Gall stones develop by 4-5 years of age.
Splenectomy does not protect against developing gall stones.
At least 25 % cases have a family history of HS.
High MCH is pathognomonic of HS.

questions.solution:
Among the given statements about hereditary spherocytosis, the true statement is option c– at least 25% of cases have a familial inheritance (as 75% of cases show an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern)

Hereditary spherocytosis is a type of hereditary hemolytic anemia that is mostly inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Some of the cases can be autosomal recessive or sporadic. Mutations of the red blood cell surface proteins spectrin and ankyrin can result in unstable cell membranes, leading to hemolysis. 

The following mutations have been identified in hereditary spherocytosis:

Autosomal dominant (more common):

  • Ankyrin - most common
  • Band 3
  • β-Spectrin

Autosomal recessive:

  • α-Spectrin
  • Band 4.2

This disorder can present at a young age with severe jaundice and fatigue. The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia predisposes the patient to develop gallstones in early adulthood. Pigment stones are found in 40-50% of the affected adults.

Laboratory findings include normocytic anemia with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The peripheral smear will show large spherical red blood cells without central pallor. 

MCHC (not, MCH) is increased in hereditary spherocytosis; however, it is not pathognomonic as it could be found in other conditions as well. MCV is mildly decreased because of cell shrinkage. There is mild to moderate anemia, therefore, MCH could be slightly lower. 

The diagnosis can be confirmed by the acid glycerol lysis test and the eosin-5′-maleimide (EMA)–binding test. 

There is no specific treatment available besides splenectomy. Spleen is the major site where spherocytes undergo hemolysis. Hence, splenectomy corrects the anemia and its associated complications, thereby playing a role in preventing gallstones. It is done at 4–6 years of age in severe cases and after puberty in moderate cases. It should be followed up with the appropriate antibiotic and vaccine prophylaxis.

questions.text: B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time due to which phenomenon?
questions.solution:
B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time due to alternative RNA splicing.

Alternative RNA splicing is the process by which different proteins are produced from the same RNA transcript by splicing it in different ways.

Mature circulating B cells initially express IgM and IgD antibodies on their surfaces before they are stimulated to produce specific antibodies. The heavy chains in IgM and IgD are mu (μ) and delta (δ), respectively. The mu and delta genes for these heavy chains are located proximal to the VDJ encoding regions (i.e., variable, diversity, and joining regions) of the heavy chain locus. A primary RNA transcript of this entire region is produced, which then undergoes alternative RNA processing, enabling the production of both transmembrane IgM and IgD on B cells.

Other options:

Options A and C: Somatic hypermutation is a cellular response by which the immune system adapts to the new foreign elements that confront it. They do so by adding nucleotides in V gene regions of heavy and light chains, resulting in a better fit of antigen with the antibodies. This hence increases the affinity of antibodies to antigens. Due to this, the subset of plasma cells with these improved hypervariable regions are more strongly selected by the antigen and therefore constitute a larger part of the population of antibody-producing cells. This process is called affinity maturation.

Option D: Allelic exclusion is the process by which a cell expresses one of the two alleles of the gene and excludes the other allele. 

B cells are diploid, therefore, each B cell has six gene segment pools related to antibody chains:

  • Two heavy-chain pools (one from each parent) and
  • Four light-chain pools (one κ and one λ from each parent).

However, each B cell uses only two of the six gene segment pools: one out of the two heavy-chain pools (maternal and paternal) and one out of the four light-chain pools. Thus, each B cell must choose not only between its κ and λ light-chain pools but also between its maternal and paternal light-chain and heavy-chain pools. This process of choosing is by allelic exclusion.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true regarding sirtuins?

1. Increases insulin sensitivity and thus glucose metabolism.

2. Promotes genes that increase longevity.

3. They are of 7 types.

4. They are one of the types of histone deacetylases.
questions.solution:
The true statements regarding sirtuins are 1, 2, 3, and 4 (option B).

Sirtuins are a class of proteins that possess either mono-ADP-ribosyltransferase or deacetylase activity. They have been shown to slow down the aging process.

Sirtuins promote the expression of several genes whose products increase longevity. These include proteins that:

  • Inhibit metabolic activity
  • Reduce apoptosis
  • Stimulate protein folding
  • Inhibit the harmful effects of oxygen-free radicals
  • Increase insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism (maybe targeted for the treatment of diabetes)
  • Ensure that damaged DNA is not propagated, preventing the accumulation of mutations
  • Promotes replicative senescence under chronic stress

Sirtuins level increases by caloric restriction and are present in red wine.

Sirtuins are responsible for an increase in insulin sensitivity. Hence, they can play an important role in the treatment of diabetes.

questions.text:
Match the following cells with their locations.
1. Kupffer cells a. Stomach
2. Parietal cells b. Liver 
3. Dust cells c. Alveoli
4. Clara cells d. Bronchioles
questions.solution:
The correctly matched set of the cells and their locations is 1-b, 2-a, 3-c, 4-d.

Kupffer cells are a component of the mononuclear phagocytic system and are located in the liver.

Parietal cells, also called oxyntic cells, are found in the upper half of the gastric glands. They have numerous mitochondria and are actively involved in the secretion of hydrochloric acid and intrinsic factor - a glycoprotein that aids in the absorption of vitamin B12 from the ileum. 

Dust cells are macrophages in the walls of the alveoli. They phagocytose dust particles in the alveoli. In CHF these macrophages phagocytose erythrocytes that escape from the capillaries. The cells acquire a brick-red color and are called heart failure cells.

Clara cells are non-ciliated cuboidal epithelial cells that secrete important defense markers and serve as stem cells after injury. These cells make up a larger portion of the epithelial lining in the later portions of the conducting airway.

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines is not involved in Th1 response?
questions.solution:
The cytokine not involved in TH1 response is IL-4.

Dendritic cells and macrophages present antigens to T helper cells (TH) after which they differentiate into TH1 and TH2 cells. They are responsible for cell-mediated and humoral immune responses, respectively. IL-12 is secreted by macrophages and promotes the proliferation of TH1 cells.

TH1 cells secrete:

  • IL-2 which activates natural killer cells (NK cells) and cytotoxic T cells
  • IFN gamma which stimulates macrophages and is also responsible for delayed hypersensitivity along with TGF beta.

TH2 cells secrete: 

  • IL- 4 stimulates IgE production from B cells
  • IL- 5 stimulates proliferation of eosinophils and together play a role in helminthic and allergic reactions
  • IL- 6 promotes proliferation of B cells and production of antibodies.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl presents with a midline neck swelling that moves on deglutition. USG revealed a 2 cm x 2 cm nodule on the left lobe of the thyroid, extending into the strap muscles. The histopathology image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image showing papillae lined by cells with overlapping nuclei and Orphan Annie eye nuclei indicate a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of thyroid.

Papillary carcinoma of thyroid presents as a painless nodule or mass in the neck or cervical node in women of reproductive age. The risk factors include exposure to ionizing radiation and Hashimoto thyroiditis.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on a scan. Histopathological examination shows branching papillae and follicles with fibrovascular stalk. Nuclear changes include ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei, pseudo-inclusions, and nuclear grooves. Psammoma bodies are often present.

Diagnosis can be made based on these nuclear features, even in the absence of papillary architecture. The prognosis is excellent, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

 

The image below shows Orphan Annie eye nuclei with central clearing and margination of chromatin:

 

Other options:

Option A: Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is a neuroendocrine tumor that is derived from parafollicular C cells, that secrete calcitonin.

Most of these tumors occur sporadically. Some are associated with familial multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndrome: MEN 2A and MEN 2B. They frequently present as a neck mass that may be associated with cervical lymphadenopathy. With the enlargement of the nodule, patients may have dysphagia and dyspnea. 

Histopathology shows polygonal to spindle-shaped cells which form nests, trabeculae, or follicles. Amyloid deposits that are derived from the altered calcitonin molecules are present in the stroma. Calcitonin in the tumor cells and stroma is easily demonstratable by immunohistochemistry.

 

Option B: Follicular carcinoma thyroid on histopathology may show uniform cells forming small follicles containing colloid (resembling normal thyroid gland) or sheets of cells without colloid.

 

Anaplastic carcinomas are poorly differentiated thyroid carcinomas with varied morphology including giant cells or spindle-shaped cells or both. There is minimal follicular differentiation with intratumoral necrosis.

 

Option C: A thyroglossal duct cyst is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood often noticed after an upper respiratory infection.

It represents the persistence of the track of the thyroid gland and can be found adjacent to the midline. It presents as smooth, fluctuant (cystic) swelling that is often transilluminant. Classically, the cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion. 

Sistrunk’s operation is performed to excise the cyst and prevent a recurrence.

questions.text: A chronic smoker with a smoking history of 24 packs presents with breathlessness and chest pain. Further investigations revealed the presence of a lung tumor. On staining, cells are positive for chromogranin. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a lung tumor associated with chronic smoking and tumor cells staining positive for chromogranin indicates that the most likely diagnosis in this patient is small cell carcinoma of the lung.

Small cell carcinoma of the lung belongs to the neuroendocrine tumors and originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells, Kulchitsky cells that line the bronchial epithelium. It is a highly malignant tumor with a high association with cigarette smoking. It usually arises from the major bronchi.

Histopathology of small cell lung carcinoma shows clusters of small cells which are round, oval, or spindle-shaped, and a prominent nuclear molding. These cells have scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli. The Azzopardi effect is described as basophilic staining of vascular walls due to coating by DNA from necrotic tumor cells.

Neuroendocrine markers seen in small cell lung carcinoma include:

  • Chromogranin
  • Synaptophysin
  • CD56

Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with small cell carcinoma of the lung are Cushing syndrome due to ACTH production and hyponatremia due to inappropriate ADH secretion. Small cell lung cancer-associated SIADH is due to the ectopic release of antidiuretic hormone. It is associated with increased thirst and hyponatremia. 

Other options:

Option A- Adenocarcinoma is a malignant epithelial tumor with differentiation in glands or mucin production by the tumor cells. These tumors are commonly found in women and in non-smokers. These tumors are more peripherally located and are smaller. On histopathology, the tumor shows a lepidic pattern of spread with tumor cells crawling along the normal-appearing alveolar septa. The tumor cells are positive for thyroid transcription factor 1 (TTF-1) and Napsin A.

Option B- Squamous cell carcinoma is found to be more common in men and has a strong association with smoking. They have precursor lesions like squamous dysplasia, squamous metaplasia, or in situ carcinomas. On histopathology, it is characterized by keratinization and/or intercellular bridges. Keratinization occurs in the form of squamous pearls. It is positive for p40 and p63 markers. Hypercalcemia is the common paraneoplastic syndrome associated with this type.

Option C- Large cell carcinoma is an undifferentiated malignant epithelial carcinoma. On histopathology, the cells are large, with large nuclei, prominent nucleoli with a moderate amount of cytoplasm.

questions.text: A male patient presented with hemoptysis. On examination, hilar mass was present. The histopathological image is shown below. Immunohistochemistry revealed that the cells were positive for p40. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the histopathological findings showing keratin pearls are suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma of the lung. 

Squamous cell carcinoma is most commonly found in men and is strongly associated with smoking. 

Squamous cell carcinoma predominantly arises in the central segmental or subsegmental bronchi. The tumor may grow into the bronchial lumen and produce an intraluminal mass. In certain cases, the bronchial obstruction may lead to atelectasis or infection. The tumor may penetrate the wall of the bronchus and infiltrate the peribronchial tissue into the carina or the mediastinum. 

This tumor may be associated with paraneoplastic syndromes like hypercalcemia. The symptoms could include anorexia, nausea, vomiting, constipation, lethargy, polyuria, polydipsia, and dehydration.

Squamous metaplasia and dysplasia often precede frank squamous cell carcinoma. Carcinoma in-situ persists for many years and this may often be recognized on cytologic smears or in BAL fluid or brushings.

Gross appearance: The tissue is grey-white, firm, with areas of necrosis and hemorrhages. Red or yellow-white mottling and softening may be seen. The necrotic foci may cavitate. 

Histopathology: They have precursor lesions like squamous dysplasia, squamous metaplasia, or in situ carcinomas. On histopathology, it is characterized by keratinization and/or intercellular bridges. Keratinization occurs in the form of squamous pearls or individual cells with dense eosinophilic cytoplasm. It is positive for p40 and p63 markers.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about proto-oncogenes?

1. KIT has decreased expression via the tyrosine kinase signaling pathway in GIST.
2. KRAS mutation is more commonly associated with small-cell lung cancer.
3. ERBB2 is over-expressed in association with breast carcinomas.
4. PDGFR-β has suppressed expression in colorectal cancers.
questions.solution:
The true statement about proto-oncogenes is statement 3. ERBB2 amplification (gene that encodes HER2) is associated with breast cancer, while ERBB 1 mutation (gene that encodes EGFR) is associated with adenocarcinoma of the lung. 

Other statements:

Statement 1: The most common genetic change in GISTs is the gain-of-function mutation of the tyrosine kinase KIT gene. These are present in 75% to 85% of all GISTs. Therefore KIT has increased expression in GIST.

The second most common mutation results in the activation of platelet-derived growth factor receptor A (PDGFRA).

Statement 2: KRAS mutation is associated with colon, lung, and pancreatic tumors. Among lung cancers, about 30% of cases of adenocarcinoma have gain of function mutations of the KRAS gene.

Small cell carcinomas are associated with the inactivation of TP53 and RB genes.

Statement 4: PDGFR-β amplification is associated with gliomas and leukemias. PDGF-β overexpression is associated with astrocytoma.

Mutations involved in colon cancer pathogenesis:

  • Familial adenomatous polyposis usually has mutations involving the APC gene.
  • HNPCC- majority of the cases have mutations in MSH2 or MLH1.
  • Adenocarcinomas- the two pathways implicated are the APC pathway and MSI pathway.

  • PDGF receptor A
  • CD34

  • M/C symptom: Upper GI bleeding
  • Other symptoms: Pain, lump, perforation, incidental finding

  • IOC for recurrent GIST: PET-CT

  • Route of metastasis: Hematogenous

  • Prognosis is determined by: Mitotic index, tumor size & location of tumor (Stomach GISTs are less aggressive).
  • Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used.

questions.text: The given peripheral smear is associated with which of the following leukemias?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear findings point toward a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

The peripheral smear shows smudge cells, increased lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm, and round to slightly irregular nuclei containing clumped chromatin. This large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes is often described as a "convent-girl" appearance.

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)/ Small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL) is the most common leukemia among adults in the western world. The differentiating point between CLL and SLL is that the absolute lymphocyte count is >5000/mm³ in CLL and <5000/mm³ in SLL.

 The chromosomal defects:

  • Deletion of 13q (commonest and has a good prognosis)
  • Deletion of 11q
  • Trisomy 12q
  • Deletion of 17p (poor prognosis)

It is usually asymptomatic at diagnosis but can present with easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. Generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are usually seen.

Total blood count: 

  • Total leukocyte count is highly variable; leukopenia is seen when the marrow is involved. 
  • Hypogammaglobulinemia is common and contributes to increased susceptibility to infections.
  • 10% to 15% of patients develop hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia due to autoantibodies made by non-neoplastic B cells.

Findings of peripheral smear:

  • Predominantly shows small lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm.
  • Contains a large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes, which is often described as a convent-girl appearance.
  • Smudge cells or basket cells or parachute cells - artifacts of the lymphocytes which are disrupted during the process of making smears.
  • Spherocytes (due to coexisting autoimmune hemolytic anemia) and nucleated RBCs (due to premature release of progenitors in face of severe anemia, marrow infiltration by the tumor, or both)

Lymph node biopsy: Diffuse effacement of lymph node architecture is seen. Small lymphocytes admixed with variable numbers of larger activated lymphocytes that often gather in loose aggregates. Proliferation centers containing mitotically active cells are pathognomonic for CLL / SLL.

The histopathological image shows small, darker staining lymphocytes with prominent nucleoli, which are typically seen in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).

AML is a hematopoietic progenitor malignancy that causes immature myeloblast accumulation in the bone marrow. Incidence increases with age and peaks after 60 years of age.

Clinically, the patients present with symptoms resulting due to pancytopenia (anemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia). There is generalized fatigue, bone pain, bleeding tendencies, and an increased risk of recurrent infections. For acute myeloblastic leukemia (AML) diagnosis, the blast cell count should be ≥20% in the peripheral blood or bone marrow.

Other distinctive features of AML:

  • Bone marrow/ smear shows a large, uniform population of cells (myeloblasts) with prominent nucleoli (yellow arrow). It shows the presence of primary cytoplasmic granules.
  • Auer rods: needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies formed by the fusion of lysosomes. (black arrow)
  • Multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks known as faggot cells (seen in peripheral smear).

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) arises from immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells called lymphoblasts. Immunohistochemistry for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) is positive in pre-B and pre-T lymphoblasts.

Peripheral smear shows lymphoblasts that have condensed chromatin, less conspicuous nucleoli, and smaller amounts of cytoplasm which lacks granules as shown below.

Chronic myeloid leukemia is characterized by the presence of a Philadelphia chromosome resulting from reciprocal translocation t(9;22) forming the BCR-ABL fusion gene. They have hypercellular marrow due to a massively increased number of maturing granulocytic precursors.

The image below shows peripheral smear findings of CML with neutrophils, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band cells.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about familial adenomatous polyposis?
  1. It is autosomal recessive.
  2. If not treated, 100% of the cases progress to adenocarcinoma colon.
  3. It is associated with a gene mutation in KRAS.
  4. It is associated with congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium.
questions.solution:
The true statements about familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) are statements 2 and 4 (option- A).

Familial adenomatous polyposis is an inherited autosomal dominant disorder presenting numerous colorectal adenomatous polyps. It is an autosomal dominant disease caused by mutations in the APC gene, which is a regulator in the Wnt signaling pathway. The diagnosis of FAP requires the presence of at least 100 polyps.

Patients are usually teenagers and multiple polyps are visible in the colon during sigmoidoscopy. It is associated with a variety of extraintestinal manifestations including congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigmental epithelium. Colorectal adenocarcinoma occurs in almost all cases before the age of 50. 

Prophylactic colectomy is recommended in patients with APC gene mutations. The surgeries used are colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis (IRA), restorative proctocolectomy with an ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (RPC), or total proctectomy and end ileostomy. The first 2 surgeries are preferred in young patients as it avoids a permanent stoma. 

Note - FAP along with brain tumors is called Turcot syndrome. FAP along with multiple osteomas, skin, and soft tissue tumors is called Gardner syndrome.

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text: Which of the following shows maximum amplitude on thromboelastography?
questions.solution:
The maximum amplitude in thromboelastography represents platelets. A decrease in maximum amplitude signifies a quantitative or qualitative deficiency of platelets.

Thromboelastography (TEG) is a non-invasive test that quantifies the ability of whole blood to form a clot. It is useful in intraoperative coagulation status assessment. The dynamic changes in the viscoelastic properties of a blood sample during the clotting can be detected and quantified by thromboelastography. Underlying coagulation deficiencies show different shapes in the TEG. They are shown in the image below:

 

Advantages of thromboelastography:

  • Blood coagulability, including coagulation cascade, platelet function, and fibrinolysis can be assessed. 
  • It is a simple bedside test
  • Can diagnose coagulopathic bleeding
  • Can be used as a guide in transfusion therapy and decrease the use of blood products
  • Can detect dynamic changes in blood coagulation during resuscitation
  • Predict the clinical efficacy of therapeutic agents affecting blood coagulability

The probable diagnosis from the given clinical scenario and the histopathological description is Hodgkin's lymphoma. The bi-nucleated cells are called the Reed-Sternberg cells which are CD 15+ and CD30+ (option D- 1 and 2).

Hodgkin's lymphoma arises in a single lymph node or chain of nodes and spreads first to anatomically contiguous lymphoid tissues. It usually presents as painless lymphadenopathy. The distinctive feature of Hodgkin's lymphoma is the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells.

WHO classifies Hodgkin's lymphoma into 5 subtypes:

  1. Nodular sclerosis: Frequent lacunar cells
  2. Mixed cellularity
  3. Lymphocyte-rich
  4. Lymphocyte depletion
  5. Nodular lymphocyte predominance

The first 4 subtypes are considered classical Hodgkin's lymphoma. The RS cells are CD 15+ and CD30+. The lymphocyte predominant type is considered non-classical Hodgkin's lymphoma with CD15-, CD30-, CD20+, and EB -.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy presented with fatigue. Investigations revealed: Hemoglobin, 9 g/dL; MCV, 60 fL; MCH, 20 pg; and serum ferritin, 185 μg/L. The TLC was elevated and showed predominant lymphocytes and neutrophils. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?

Normal values:

  • Serum Ferritin: 50-150 μg/L 
  • Mean cell volume (MCV)-  80-100 fL
  • Mean cell Hb (MCH)- 27–31 pg

TLC- Total leukocyte count
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the investigation findings are suggestive of microcytic hypochromic anemia. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is anemia of chronic disorder. 

Anemia of chronic disorders more commonly presents as normochromic normocytic anemia that later develops into microcytic hypochromic anemia rarely. It is caused due to production of erythrocytes. 

Anemia of chronic disease is anemia resulting due to chronic diseases which produce systemic inflammation. During chronic inflammation, inflammatory mediators like interleukin - 6 (IL-6) stimulate the production of hepcidin from the liver. Hepcidin is an acute phase reactant that inhibits ferroportin on macrophages and also decreases transport of iron from stores to developing RBC precursors. This results in decreased proliferation of erythroid progenitors due to impaired iron utilization.

Other options:

Option B: Thalassemia also presents as iron deficiency anemia but it does not have elevated luekocytosis. 

Option C: Iron deficiency anemia also presents as microcytic hypochromic anemia. But since there is deficient iron, the serum ferritin level will also be low. This patient has normal serum ferritin and hence does not have iron deficiency anemia. 

Note: 

MCV/RBC count (Mentzer index) can also be used to distinguish thalassemia from iron-deficiency anemia (IDA). MCV (mean corpuscular volume) and MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin) are low in both IDA and thalassemia. RBC count may be normal in thalassemia, whereas it is reduced in IDA. A lower RBC count in IDA means the denominator is smaller, yielding a greater MCV/RBC ratio.

Option D: Sickle cell anemia is caused by a mutation in β-globin that creates sickle hemoglobin (HbS). It does not present as microcytic hypochromic anemia.

questions.text: Senile atrophy occurs due to ______.
questions.solution:
Senile atrophy is seen when there is a reduced blood supply to a tissue. This reduction in the blood supply occurs in a gradual manner because of slowly progressing atherosclerotic lesions.

Atrophy is a process of reduction in the size of a tissue or an organ resulting from a decrease in the cell size and number. It is a type of cellular adaptation. In this process, there is a decrease in the synthesis of cellular proteins and an increase in their degradation, mainly mediated by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. Atrophy can either be physiological or pathological:

Physiologic atrophy:

  • Loss of hormonal stimulation: Atrophy of the uterus after parturition; atrophy of the endometrium, vaginal epithelium, and breast after menopause.
  • During embryonic development: Certain structures, like the notochord and thyroglossal duct, undergo atrophy during fetal development.

Pathologic atrophy:

  • Disuse Atrophy (decreased workload): e.g., atrophy in a limb that has been immobilized following a fracture
  • Denervation atrophy (loss of nerve supply): e.g., skeletal muscle atrophy following nerve injury
  • Ischemic atrophy: e.g., senile atrophy of the brain and heart due to atherosclerosis
  • Inadequate nutrition: e.g., severe muscle wasting in marasmus
  • Pressure atrophy: e.g., atrophy of surrounding uninvolved tissues caused by an enlarging benign tumor

questions.text: Cyclooxygenase plays a role in which pathway?
questions.solution:
Prostaglandins are produced from arachidonic acid present in the membrane phospholipids. This process is mediated by 2 cyclooxygenases: COX-1 and COX-2. Prostaglandins are produced by mast cells, macrophages, and endothelial cells.

COX-1 is commonly found in most tissues. It plays a role in maintaining normal homeostasis. It is also induced by inflammatory stimuli.

COX-2 is found in cells that are involved in inflammatory reactions.

The most important prostaglandins in inflammation are PGE2, PGD2, PGF2a, PGI2 (prostacyclin), and thromboxane A2.

Other options:

Options A: Kreb's cycle is also called the citric acid cycle and tricarboxylic acid cycle. It is the terminal pathway for the oxidative catabolism of carbohydrates, amino acids, and fatty acids.

Option C: Leukotrienes are also produced from arachidonic acid with the help of lipoxygenases.

questions.text: Metastatic calcification can be explained by all, except ______.
questions.solution:
Metastatic calcification cannot be explained by vitamin D deficiency. Metastatic calcification is associated with hypercalcemia, which may be caused by vitamin D intoxication rather than deficiency.

Pathologic calcification is the abnormal tissue deposition of calcium salts, together with smaller amounts of iron, magnesium, and other mineral salts. It is of two types namely metastatic and dystrophic calcification.

Metastatic calcification is the deposition of calcium salts in otherwise normal tissues.

  • Hypercalcemia secondary to some disturbance in calcium metabolism.
  • Principal causes of hypercalcemia:
    • Increased secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH)
    • Resorption of bone tissue
    • Vitamin-D-related disorders- excess or abnormal sensitivity
    • Renal failure
    • Aluminum intoxication
    • Milk-alkali syndrome- due to excess ingestion of calcium

Metastatic calcification can be seen in interstitial tissues of the gastric mucosa, kidneys, lungs, systemic arteries, and pulmonary veins.

2. IL-5 B. Mast cells

Cytokines are proteins produced by many cell types (principally activated lymphocytes, macrophages, and dendritic cells, but also endothelial, epithelial, and connective tissue cells) that mediate and regulate immune and inflammatory reactions.

Three subsets of CD4+ T cells secrete different types of cytokines and elicit different types of inflammation.

TH1 cells - activate macrophages by the classical pathway by secreting IFN­γ.

TH2 cells - recruit and activate eosinophils and are responsible for the alternative pathway of macrophage activation by secreting IL­4, IL5, and IL­13.

  • IL4 acts on B cells to stimulate class switching to IgE and promotes the development of additional TH2 cells.
  • IL5 is involved in the development and activation of eosinophils, which are essential effectors of type I hypersensitivity
    (discussed later).
  • IL13 enhances IgE production and acts on epithelial cells to stimulate mucus secretion. In addition, TH2 cells (as well as mast cells and epithelial cells) produce chemokines that attract more TH2 cells, as well as other leukocytes, to the reaction site. It also shares some functional similarities to IL-4 and can thus induce differentiation in dendritic cells.

TH17 cells secrete IL­17 and other cytokines responsible for neutrophils and monocyte recruitment.

questions.text: The following is a histopathological image of thyroid pathology. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image shows the presence of amyloid-rich stroma (pinkish material) and nests of polygonal cells, which are findings suggestive of medullary carcinoma of thyroid.

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid (MTC) arises from the parafollicular C cells. Most of the MTC are sporadic, but they may also be associated with inheritable syndromes like familial MTC, MEN2A, and MEN2B. All the inherited variants are secondary to RET gene mutations.

Most patients present at 50–60 years and have a female preponderance. MTC secretes calcitonin, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), prostaglandins E2 and F2α, histaminase, serotonin, and adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH).

Features of MTC

  • Painful neck mass with cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Dysphagia, dysphonia, or dyspnea if there is local invasion
  • Diarrhea due to increased intestinal motility
  • Cushingoid habitus due to ectopic ACTH production
  • Blood-borne metastasis 
  • Microscopically, they consist of sheets of neoplastic cells separated by collagen and amyloid stroma

Diagnosis is by careful family history, physical examination, raised calcitonin and CEA levels, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass.

Other options:

Option B: The image below shows Orphan Annie-eye nuclei with central clearing and margination of chromatin in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Option C: Follicular carcinoma thyroid on histopathology may show uniform cells forming small follicles containing colloid (resembling normal thyroid gland) or sheets of cells without colloid.

Option D: Anaplastic carcinomas are poorly differentiated thyroid carcinomas with varied morphology, including giant cells or spindle-shaped cells or both. There is minimal follicular differentiation with intratumoral necrosis.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with fever, erythematous rash, and bone pain. X-ray of the skull shows multiple lytic lesions. Skin biopsy shows prominent nuclear grooves with eosinophils as in the image below. Immunohistochemistry for S100, CD1a is also shown in the images below. What would be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the histopathological image showing Langerhans cells with folded nuclei (image A), CD1a (image B), and positive S100 (image C), is suggestive of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).

LCH occurs due to the proliferation of a special type of immature dendritic cells, called Langerhans cells. Their normal function is to present antigens. The most common mutation is the BRAFV600E gain-of-function mutation.

It is characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions and can also infiltrate nearly every organ, like the skin (of the scalp), lungs, liver, spleen, bone marrow, or the central nervous system. 

LCH can present as the following clinical entities:

  • Multifocal multisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis (Letterer-Siwe disease) - mostly seen in infants
  • Unifocal and multifocal unisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis (eosinophilic granuloma) - The combination of bone defects, diabetes insipidus, and exophthalmos is called the Hand-Schüller-Christian triad - mostly seen in younger children
  • Pulmonary LCH - mostly seen in adults

Clinical features include pain and swelling in the affected area. When calvarium is affected, it results in otitis media and mastoiditis. Spinal involvement results in compression fractures and neurological involvement. Vertebral involvement results in a rapid flattening of the vertebral body (vertebra plana).

Histopathologically, Langerhans cells have a single large nucleus with a characteristic folded or grooved nucleus (coffee-bean appearance) with small inconspicuous nucleoli. Birbeck granules are seen in the cytoplasm. The tumor cells specifically express HLA-DR, S-100, and CD1a and langerin (CD207) markers.

The image below shows a histopathological image of Langerhans cells with folded nuclei.

The presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is a characteristic finding of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) on electron microscopy.

Birbeck granules have a dilated terminal end producing a tennis racket–like appearance. It contains the protein langerin (CD207). It is seen on electron microscopy. The image below shows Birbeck granules on electron microscopy seen in LCH.

The below image shows lytic lesion of skull seen in LCH.

Option A: Rosai-Dorfman syndrome is otherwise called sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy. Rosai-Dorfman disease is not a histiocytic neoplasm. It is an idiopathic disease characterized by Painless lymphadenopathy, usually of cervical nodes. The disorder predominantly affects children, adolescents, and young adults. It may present with nonspecific symptoms and management mostly involves observation rather than specific treatment.  

Option B: Kimura disease is s a chronic inflammatory disorder of unknown etiology that most commonly presents as painless lymphadenopathy.

Option D: Juvenile xanthogranuloma is a non-Langerhans cell histiocytosis occurring in early infancy and childhood. It presents as reddish-brown papular lesions, which evolve to become orange. The lesions are most frequently seen in the face, scalp, and upper torso. They may be single or multiple lesions. Single lesions are the most common. The characteristic multinucleated giant cell, Touton cell is observed in 85% of juvenile xanthogranulomas.

2. Faggot cell b. Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma

The correct matches are as follows:

1. Popcorn cell b. Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma
2. Faggot cell a. Acute promyelocytic leukemia
3. Cerebriform nuclei d. Sezary syndrome
4. Starry sky c. Burkitt lymphoma

 

Popcorn cell is a lymphohistiocytic (L&H) variant of Reed Steenberg (RS) cells that are characteristic of lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma. It has a delicate multilobed, puffy nucleus resembling popped corn. The image below shows a popcorn cell seen in lymphocytic predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks are known as faggot cells and are highly suggestive of acute promyelocytic leukemia. Histopathology from bone marrow aspirate reveals numerous Auer rods (needle-like azurophilic granules) in the cytoplasm of the promyelocytes. Faggot cells are shown below.

Sézary-Lutzner cells - cells with cerebriform nuclei (infolded/hyper-convoluted nuclear membrane).

The histological hallmark of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (mycosis fungoides type) is the presence of Sezary-Lutzner cells, which form band-like aggregates within the superficial dermis and invade the epidermis as single cells and small clusters called Pautrier microabscess (marked by arrow). These cells have markedly infolded nuclear membranes giving them a cerebriform contour as seen below.

Microscopy in Burkitt lymphoma shows a characteristic starry sky pattern. The neoplastic cells are homogeneous, medium-sized B cells with frequent mitotic figures and reactive macrophages scattered through the tumor, with their pale cytoplasm in a background of blue-staining tumor cells giving the tumor a so-called "starry sky" appearance.

The image given below shows a starry sky pattern seen in Burkitt lymphoma.

questions.text: Hereditary angioedema is due to a defect in which of the proteins mentioned below?
questions.solution:
Hereditary angioedema is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by a deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitors. C1 esterase inhibitors usually target proteases like C1r and C1s, factor XII and the kallikrein system. Therefore, their deficiency leads to unregulated activation of kallikrein, leading to increased bradykinin.

Clinical features include swelling of the skin and mucosal surfaces, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, which may be aggravated after minor trauma or emotional stress. The condition can be treated by giving C1 inhibitor concentrates from human plasma. 

The main inflammatory mediator responsible for these symptoms is bradykinin. Bradykinin is an inflammatory mediator formed by the cleavage of kininogen, in the presence of the enzyme kallikrein. Bradykinin has the following effects:

  • Increases the vascular permeability
  • Causes contraction of smooth muscle
  • Dilates the blood vessel 
  • Mediates pain

Other options:

Options B and C: Decay-accelerating factor (DAF) and CD59 are two proteins that are linked by a glycophosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor to the plasma membrane. DAF prevents the formation of C3 convertases and CD59 inhibits the formation of the MAC. An acquired deficiency of the enzyme that creates GPI anchors leads to a deficiency of these regulators and excessive complement activation and lysis of red cells resulting in Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria(PNH).

During inflammation, C5a (Option D), C3a, and C4a, which are all cleavage products of their corresponding complement components, stimulate mast cells to release histamine. They have effects similar to those of mast cell mediators involved in anaphylactic reactions and therefore, are called anaphylatoxins. C5a is also chemotactic for neutrophils, monocytes, eosinophils, and basophils. Additionally, it activates the lipooxygenase pathway of arachidonic acid metabolism in neutrophils and monocytes, resulting in the further release of inflammatory mediators.
