A 35-year-old woman presents with fatigue. Investigations revealed the following: Hb, 5 gm %; MCH, 24; low MCV; leukocytes, 11,000/uL, and platelets, 5 lakhs. The peripheral smear is shown below. What is the diagnosis?

Normal values:

  • Mean cell volume (MCV): 90 ± 8 fL
  • Mean cell Hb (MCH): 30 ± 3 pg
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a 35 year old woman, her iron profile and peripheral smear showing microcytic hypochromic anemia are suggestive of iron-deficiency anemia (IDA).

IDA is an example of microcytic hypochromic anemia. The causes of IDA can be inadequate diet, impaired reabsorption, increased requirement and increased blood loss.

The manifestations of IDA depend upon the underlying cause. In general, IDA presents with koilonychia, alopecia, atrophic changes in the tongue, gastric mucosa, malabsorbtion and pica (craving for consumption of non-edible materials)

Peripheral smears show small and pale red cells typically described as microcytic (reduced MCV) and hypochromic (enlarged zone of central pallor). Poikilocytosis can be seen in the form of elongated red cells, known as pencil cells. Target cells can be found in cases of severe IDA.

Diagnosis is mainly by laboratory studies. The typical findings are:

  • Low hemoglobin and hematocrit
  • Low serum iron and ferretin
  • Increased Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)
  • Hepcidin is low (decreased stores of iron inhibit hepcidin synthesis)

IDA is treated by giving oral and parenteral preparations if iron or packed cell transfusion depending upon the severity of the anemia.

Option A: Megaloblastic anemia is defined by a high MCV

Option C: Thalassemia presents much earlier in infancy, with reduced MCV and a normal/increased RBC count

Option D: Essential thrombocytosis is characterized by isolated rise in platelet count (>450,000) along with normal hemoglobin, hematocrit and iron stores.

questions.text:
A chronic smoker presents to the clinic with shortness of breath. A mass is noted at the lower lobe periphery of the lung. A diagnosis of lung adenocarcinoma is made. The biopsy will be positive for:

1. Thyroid transcription factor-1 
2. p40
3. Napsin A
4. Chromogranin
questions.solution:
The biopsy of adenocarcinoma of the lung will be positive for thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) and napsin A.

Adenocarcinoma is an invasive malignant epithelial tumor with glandular differentiation or mucin production by the tumor cells. It is associated with tobacco smoking, but less so than other histologic subtypes. It is the most common subtype in non-smokers and is associated with the loss of function of EGFR, ALK, ROS1, MET or RET genes.

The majority express TTF-1, which is a protein required for normal lung development. Napsin A is a new marker and is more sensitive and specific than TTF-1 in the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma.

Adenocarcinomas grow in various patterns: acinar, lepidic, papillary, micropapillary, and solid. The lesions are small and are usually located in the periphery.  At the periphery of the tumor there is often a lepidic pattern of spread, in which the tumor cells “crawl” along normal-appearing alveolar septa. 

Clinical features usually have an insidious onset. The incidence is usually at age 50 or more. The major presenting complaints are cough, weight loss, chest pain, and dyspnea.    

Other options:

Option B: p40, along with p63 is a marker for squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.

Option D: Chromogranin is a marker for small cell carcinoma of the lung.

questions.text: The following image shows an instrument used to estimate hemoglobin levels. What does it measure?
questions.solution:
The instrument in the image is Sahli's hemoglobinometer and is used to measure acid hematin levels of a given blood sample. 

In Sahli's method, oxyhemoglobin is converted to acid hematin with the action of dilute hydrochloric acid (N/10 HCl). The brown color of the acid hematin is matched to its intensity with a standard brown glass comparator in a visual colorimeter called Sahli’s colorimeter.

Sahli's method is a simple bedside test and is cost-effective. However, it has some disadvantages which include visual errors, inability to measure other forms of hemoglobin, fading of the comparator over time, and the color of acid hematin fading quickly.

questions.text: A woman presents with lesions on the inner thighs and peri-anal region. They are nodular,  4-6 mm in size, and appear pale. The histopathological image shows multiple intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies consistent with Henderson-Patterson bodies. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the histological image is molluscum contagiosum, which shows intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies, called Henderson–Patterson bodies or molluscum bodies.

Infection is usually spread by direct contact, particularly among children and young adults. Multiple lesions occur on the skin and mucous membranes, with a predilection for the trunk and anogenital areas. Individual lesions are firm, pruritic, pink to skin-colored umbilicated papules. A curd-like material can be expressed from the central umbilication.

Smearing this material onto a glass slide followed by Giemsa staining shows diagnostic molluscum bodies, which are ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusion bodies that are found in the cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum and are up to 35 μm in size.

The image below shows umbilicated papules of molluscum contagiosum. 

 

Other options: 

Option A: Trichodysplasia spinulosa is a condition characterized by painless erythematous papules on the face with folliculocentric keratin spines. It is caused by trichodysplasia spinulosa-associated polyomavirus. Histologic features are keratin plugging, abundant dystrophic and cornfield inner root sheath epithelium, and numerous, large eosinophilic trichohyalin granules.

Option B: Koilocytes are characteristically seen in HPV infections, such as condylomata acuminata. Koilocytes are lining cells which have perinuclear cytoplasmic vacuolization.

Option D: Donovan bodies are seen in donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. Donovan bodies are minute, encapsulated coccobacilli in macrophages, which can be demonstrated in Giemsa-stained smears of the exudate.

questions.text: Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is caused by all of the following cytokines except:
questions.solution:
INF-γ is not involved in Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (JHR).

JHR is a condition that occurs in patients infected by spirochetes who undergo antibiotic treatment. The reaction occurs within 24 hours of antibiotic treatment. Clinical features are fever, chills, nausea and vomiting, tachycardia, hypotension, flushing, myalgia, and exacerbation of skin lesions.

Syphilis is the leading spirochetal infection associated with JHR. Other infections are Lyme disease, louse-borne relapsing fever, leptospirosis, and tick-borne relapsing fever. Antibiotics that have been most associated are penicillins, tetracyclines, and erythromycin.

Mild reactions are self-limiting and often resolve spontaneously within 24 hours. Prevention of the JHR is by giving TNF-alpha antibodies and in some cases steroids.
